ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about geological topics like mining, climate change, etc.
I learned more about the context of our world and my portfolio area

I learned SO much new material in this course that I absolutely had no prior knowledge about. I learned about tectonic plates, volcanoes, different cycles of rocks, and then was able to apply all this material to a location of choosing, which I loved.
I learned a lot about my hometown as learning about its geography was the overall theme of the class.
I learned how to see geology in everyday life, beyond just rocks. I learned about geologic processes and other earth processes, and learned how to comprehensively analyze an area.
learned of basic geology, especially the geology of my hometown!
General knowledge of earth science and geology.

This is the greatest science class of all time. Professor Evans is so kind and knowledgeable and genuinely gets non-stem students excited about science by allowing them to view EPS through the lens of a portfolio location of which the student is most likely familiar with.
I gained a foundation of geology and earth sciences. I am not a science geared person, but Professor Evans cultivated a wonderful environment to learn in; I always looked forward to lecture.
Rock formations and how geology impacts life in a tangible way
I learned a lot about geology and how it impacts the earth.
I learned more about geology on a basic level, including more about my hometown thanks to the semester-long assignment and relevant homework questionsI really appreciated this!
I learned about the geological processes of my own town and began to be more curious about the environmental things I see. If I see a rock, I will try to identify its lithology.
very accessible introduction to geology. I learned a ton and was engaged throughout!
Overview of geology for a beginner!
An overview of geology. Learned about land, rocks, natural disasters, and climate change.
I developed a better understanding of the processes that shape the Earth's formation and how these affect humans.

I learned a lot about a range of subjects in geology, as well as the environment and climate. I really enjoyed combining general studies of global geology with a more in-depth study of a specific location.
I learned some basic information about geology and a lot of specific information about one location, my portfolio location.
I learned about the geology of my hometown in a pretty susbtantial and serious way. I also thought about rocks and the history of development of the environment around me in ways I never have before.
I learned introductory level skills to better understand the Earth around me and ways I can continue to be fascinated by the Earths natural processes.

I learned about the geological history of my portfolio location, but also about how each topic is related. The stratigraphy is related to the soil, which ties into the resources, which contributes to development of the area, affecting population density and pollution. It is all connected.
Basic geology + environmental science.

I learned about basic geological concepts in a way that was relevant to my daily life and personal experience. I also learned a lot about the geology of my hometown specifically through the term-long portfolio assignment
I learned about how the Earth systems work and fit together!

Learned about the basics in the earth and planetary sciences field. This includes plate tectonics, geology and rock formation, natural disasters, and others. Through a semester-long project, you learn about the geologic history and implications of a chosen location.
Various maths and techniques involved in earth science.
This class gave me an overview of earth sciences concepts and taught me how to study, analyze, and understand the geologic profile of a specific location.
How the Earth works; different types of rocks; how my profile location is formed by its geological elements, such as soil and climate

I gained a comprehensive and broad understanding of the geologic and earth systems processes occurring around us. I also learned a lot about my portfolio place and its geologic history. I learned how to use Google Earth and about the importance of geology in sustainability.
Basic earth science stuff/geology
I gained a basic understanding of geology and an interest in it.
Very brief introduction to our planetary structure without much deep-dives.
I gained insights into various aspects of geology, including rock formation, stratigraphy, weather and climate, sustainability, seismology, and tectonic plates.
Concepts in geology including: stratigraphy, rivers, groundwater, climate, plate tectonics, sedimentary rocks, igneous rocks, metamorphism, soils, energy.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I wish the portfolio project was a little bit more explained in the beginning as that would help as we completed it.

Strengths: lectures are engaging and problem sets are doable (often with TA assistance)
Weaknesses: maybe make problem sets a little clearer in instructions? I feel like this was often why I went to office hours and it could've been avoided

Strength: being able to apply what you learn that week to your own location every week in a PSET and then later compiling it together for a project. The lectures are also extremely fun and engaging, which I love.

Strength - The assignments are self-explanatory and approachable. 
Weakness - None

Professor Evans is a great lecturer and really interesting guy. He kept lectures lighthearted and sprinkled in a healthy amount of bad jokes and geologic rapping. The assignments were constant but short, so the final project (which built off the assignments) was a breeze. The class was relaxed and really well-organized.

HOC Evans "Majestic D" is a gem. He is very excited about geology and the course make it so that we are interested in it, as it all leads to a final project regarding a chosen portfolio location, usually our hometown.
Less busy work and more directed learning would be helpful. Thought it was organized well and the Professor is a great lecturer.

I think in the past a weakness could be that the final project could be left to the last minute, however, this year Professor Evans responded to feedback and had students undergo research for their final project throughout the term, which is definitely very helpful for completing the final project at the end of the course

This course's strength definitely lied in its very educative manner, yet it never felt stressful, which in my opinion facilities learning all the more.

Strengths: lectures are interesting
Weaknesses: homeworks are at times unclear and as it gets more related to the particular portfolio location TFs aren't able to help as much
This course is great. The content is interesting and the learning environment doesn't feel high stakes.
No weaknesses!
I absolutely loved this course! No weaknesses!

PSETS were challenging and didn't feel like they connected to what we learned in lecture. Yes, it's gutty, but you will still need to devote several hours to the PSETs each week as they are not graded lightly. However, I do think I learned a lot through the work I did for the course.

Strengths: very engaging lectures, very accessible for beginners unfamiliar with this topic
Weaknesses: grading on homework inconsistent and nit-picky, often took away from understanding topic/working on portfolio because of worries about harsh grading
Good structured class. Can not think of any improvements.
Some of the lectures were not very engaging, even though prof. Evans tried to engage even people who weren't interested in the topic
Strengths: Interesting material, lots of support from TAs for problem sets, Prof. Evans is an amazing instructor; weaknesses: None

Strengths: most of the psets are pretty straightforward (you can do them without going to lecture) and Prof. Evans is an entertaining lecturer. Weaknesses: two of the psets were really hard for no reason and the final project is worth so much of your gradeI would much rather have had multiple interim deadlines throughout the semester than have it all due at once.

This is the perfect course for someone looking for a low-pressure introduction to geology. There were a couple homeworks (HW 9 especially) that could have been more straightforward, and perhaps multiple TAs could have been responsible for each homework in the weeks when many office hour slots were filled up. In addition, it seemed like one TA graded much more harshly than the rest, which was surprising but would not necessarily have been a problem if his expectations had been made clearer before the homework was graded. Overall, though, the combination of general lectures with specific weekly assignments culminating in a final project was great, because it enabled us to consistently and thoughtfully apply our general knowledge to a specific location that was meaningful to us, and then share that knowledge with the class and receive feedback through the video component of the final.

The grading for home works was not always straightforward, and lecture recording quality could have been better. I know the low quality recording is meant to encourage people to come to class, but on days when I couldn't make it I had no motivation to try and learn the material after listening to what essentially sounded like whale songs for 55 minutes of my life.

Strengths: Head Evans is a really engaging professor and the lectures were superb + very easy to follow along with. The material of the class was also very applicable to the real world. 

Weaknesses: sometimes it feels like the material from the lecture isnt directly applicable to the psets, which end up becoming an extremely detailed case study into a specific area of the world. Because of this I often zoned out in the lecture as there was a feeling you didnt really need to know the material

The portfolio assignment is a really great way to connect all the concepts we learned at the end of the term, and gives students a clear reason why what they are learning is relevant/relates to their life at all; the homework sets were a great mix of reviewing the content from class and then applying it to our locations; the class was structured so that even without tests I feel like I have long-term takeaways and learning that will stick with me
The course was really great.  I liked the wide availability of office hours and the amount that the professor broke down the material to a level that was easy to understand.

This course is very well-designed. I appreciated that all of the problem sets work towards piecing together the geologic profile of your portfolio final project. It was a great course for people with limited math/science backgrounds looking for a broad, interesting science course.
All strengths. This class reignited my interest in geology.

The primary strength of this class is that Professor Evans clearly knows his audience. He adjusted the course material for non-STEM majors and created lectures that were accessible and interesting for everyone. The TAs were also hugely helpful and put aside so much time to answer questions about problem sets.

The primary weakness of the class is that the skills needed to tackle the problem sets were not always covered in class. In particular, Problem Set 9 felt like a very big ask given what we had covered in class, and I know that that homework assignment was very difficult for many students. We definitely learned the concepts in class, but the applications of those concepts was not always clear.

I liked the portfolio project because it allowed us to feel personally invested in what we were doing in class, but it was hard to get specific feedback/help from TAs because everyone was studying a different location. I sometimes felt like I was flying blind or in over my head because there wasn't anyone I could get location-specific feedback from.

Strength: clear and organized information that is easy to understand; everything uploaded afterward, making it easy to reference when working on the homework; lots of office hours available each week to help with homework; introductory course that is easy for non-EPS majors to understand
Weakness: N/A
The lectures are engaging and accessible to students without any prior knowledge about the topic. Lecture recordings were helpful to look back at and the final project was meaningful and enjoyable.
Great lectures
I thought the lectures were informative and the psets a good level of work.
Weakness: class too large, office hours and TFs mostly inaccessible

Strengths: engaging and relevant lectures, lots of guidance offered in the form of abundant office hours or consultations, bits of the final project are completed each week so it is not overwhelming at the end

Weaknesses: problem sets didn't necessarily connect with information learned in class, some problem sets required outside research into your portfolio location and depending on what area you chose it could be really difficult to find information or the information was in a foreign language

The course material was fascinating! I particularly enjoyed how each student had a portfolio location that they would study throughout the semester it was a great way to learn a little about the geological history of my hometown.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to another student that needs a science credit.
Yes - it's a great science credit; you learn but aren't in over your head

Yes, it is a fun course every student should take (no matter your major)! It covers a lot of interesting topics plus will give you a bunch of knowledge about one specific place in the world of your choosing, so it is valuable information.
I would, for non STEM majors it is the best exposure to science.
Yes!!!
Absolutely! The material was so interesting and Professor Evans is a gem. The work was consistent but light and the final project is a breeze.
Absolutely! excellent science credit. this is the one to take, humanities majors.
Anyone interested in geology and earth science would love the course.
100% yes, especially if you are non-STEM and looking for an engaging science course.
For sure! Any student that is interested in earth science should definitely take this course
Nice science gut, and also very interesting if you're genuinely interested about how your life is somewhat the consequence of geology
Yes, absolutely. A great science credit for anyone even remotely interested in rocks/the earth.

YES! Even if you're taking it as an easier intro-level class, the material was engaging, Prof Evans is great, and you'll end up learning a lot of rewarding information about the geology of where you call home.
Yes! It's a great introduction to geology course. I was able to take the final project whatever direction I wanted and decided to focus on my hometown (a place I care about)

Definitely! Prof Evans engages us all so well and this is a great introductory course for geology. Also, although this is jokingly called "Rocks for Jocks", you won't be slacking off in this class and will still be learning tons. The homework sets ensure you're keeping up with the material and delving deep into your portfolio project.

Yes I would if you need a science gut. My biggest piece of advice I wish someone had told me: GO TO OFFICE HOURS!! EVERY WEEK! Meet with the TF who is grading your assignment and ask them to look it over, that way you will automatically get As on all of the assignments. If not, you risk being docked on stupid points.
Absolutely! Geology touches on so many aspects of life and it's important to understand it on a basic level.
Yes! This is a great science credit for a non-STEM student. I found the material to be very engaging and relevant to my other classes.
Yes interesting course with a great professor.
It is a great science credit for non-science majors
I would certainly recommend this course to any student who is interested in an introduction to geology and is looking to study in depth the geology of a specific location.
Yes but the final project is rough if you procrastinate until the end of the semester.
Yes! It was a great way to learn about geology and apply that knowledge to a location of personal significance.

This is a great class. Prof. Evans makes it very engaging and even if you initially take it for what seems like a low workload, you actually do end up learning a lot about your location and its geology.
Yes, it is really cool to learn in depth about the geology of a place you choose.

Yes! Professor Evans passion and knowledge for geology shines in this course, and being able to learn just introductory level geology from him was fascinating and I loved being able to grasp even a small amount of the research he is completing in his field.

I would certainly recommend this course to another student. If you have a heavy course load or need a science credit, this a great class to take. It is not necessarily a gut, but it is definitely a lighter load than most classes here.
Yes!

I am a geo major, but 99% of students take this as an "easy" or as I prefer to say accessible stem credit. I would recommend this class especially if you do not feel comfortable with math in your STEM credit.
Yes, it was a great way to try out a topic in science without too much commitment, which is hard to do in most science classes at Yale, and it was super interesting and relevant.

Yes! Professor Evans is funny and approachable. This course is good for EPS majors, potential EPS majors, and non-EPS/non-STEM people. As a non-STEM person, who hasn't taken a math or science class in a couple years, this course made the concepts accessible and easy to understand. The p-sets were not too difficult, as long as you stayed up-to-date with lecture, and helped build up for your final project, which I greatly appreciated.
Yes yes!!! 100% yes.
Yes. This course was well designed, a reasonable work load, and foundational enough to be applicable to real life (even for students that are not interested in becoming EPS majors).
YES. it was a lot of work but I truly feel like I have learned so much in such a short time.
Yes!! 100%. Prof. Evans is such a great and kind lecturer who truly believes in helping you learn and absorb the content without the unnecessary stress of exams. Great science credit!

If you are looking for a science credit, this is a great class to take. The class definitely has work, some weeks more than others, but it is very reasonable. The class is fun and interactive, and you can learn a lot if you actually pay attention.
Yes, if they are looking for an engaging science credit that doesn't take up too much time
Yes, it's fascinating and changed my perspective about the importance of geology and how it has influenced societal development.
Yes! Best class I've taken.
I would- it was a good science credit where you actually learned something, and the TFs were super helpful

I would recommend this course if a student is genuinely interested in geology and is willing to engage. I found some topics less interesting than others and could tell when I had to force myself to remain focused compared to when a topic naturally captured my attention, so for students just looking for a science credit, I think this course could actually be really tedious despite the low workload if you're not interested in the material. However, for those who are passionate about the subject, Prof. Evans is a great instructor who is always willing to discuss questions or your project and can impart a lot of knowledge. Also, the work is very manageable overall.
Yes! This is a great intro geology course.
